skill.name: reconnaissance-knowledge
skill.description: Comprehensive knowledge about network reconnaissance and service enumeration. Provides methodologies for port scanning, service fingerprinting, web directory discovery, and vulnerability identification. Includes best practices for structured data collection.
skill.summary: Educational knowledge base for authorized network reconnaissance and penetration testing methodologies
skill.author: CharlesKozel

security_audit.summary: This skill provides educational content about network reconnaissance and penetration testing methodologies. Static analysis flagged 102 patterns related to security scanning tools (nmap, masscan, gobuster, enum4linux) and network operations. All findings are false positives - the skill contains no executable code, only documentation and example commands for authorized security testing. Risk level is medium due to dual-use nature of security tools, requiring users to have proper authorization. Content is appropriate for security professionals, CTF participants, and authorized penetration testers.

medium_findings.title: Dual-Use Security Tools Documentation
medium_findings.description: The skill documents usage of security scanning tools (nmap, masscan, gobuster, enum4linux, nikto) commonly used in penetration testing. While this is educational content without executable code, these tools require proper authorization before use. The skill appropriately frames this as educational for authorized testing contexts.

content.user_title: Master Network Reconnaissance with Claude Code
content.value_statement: Security professionals need structured methodologies for authorized penetration testing and network reconnaissance. This skill provides comprehensive knowledge of reconnaissance tools, layered scanning strategies, and best practices for systematic information gathering in authorized security assessments.
actual_capabilities: Provides structured methodologies for network port scanning and service discovery using tools like nmap and masscan
Explains layered reconnaissance strategies with three escalation levels from quick scans to comprehensive enumeration
Documents web enumeration techniques using gobuster, nikto, and whatweb for directory discovery and technology identification
Includes service-specific enumeration methods for SMB, FTP, SSH, and database services with example commands
Offers JSON output templates for structured data collection and integration with penetration testing workflows
Guides users through reconnaissance phases from initial port discovery to comprehensive vulnerability assessment
limitations: Does not execute any scanning commands or perform actual reconnaissance activities
Requires users to have proper authorization before using documented techniques on any target system
Does not include exploitation techniques or vulnerability testing beyond reconnaissance
Users must have security scanning tools installed separately in their environment

use_cases.title: Security Professional Conducting Authorized Penetration Tests
use_cases.description: A penetration tester uses this knowledge base to guide Claude Code through systematic reconnaissance of an authorized target system, starting with port discovery and escalating to comprehensive service enumeration when initial scans yield limited results.
use_cases.target_user: Security professionals with authorized penetration testing engagements

use_cases.title: Student Learning Ethical Hacking in CTF Environment
use_cases.description: A cybersecurity student practicing in a Capture The Flag competition uses the layered reconnaissance framework to discover hidden services and directories on challenge machines, following best practices for structured information gathering.
use_cases.target_user: Security students and CTF participants in authorized learning environments

use_cases.title: Security Auditor Documenting Network Assessment
use_cases.description: An auditor performing a network security assessment uses the JSON output templates to ensure consistent documentation of discovered services, versions, and potential vulnerabilities across multiple systems in the authorized scope.
use_cases.target_user: Security auditors conducting authorized organizational assessments

prompt_templates.title: Basic Port Scan
prompt_templates.prompt: Using the reconnaissance knowledge, perform a quick port scan on target 10.10.10.1 to identify the top 1000 open ports. Provide the results in JSON format.
prompt_templates.scenario: Starting reconnaissance on a new authorized target system

prompt_templates.title: Web Application Enumeration
prompt_templates.prompt: The target at http://10.10.10.5 is running a web server. Use the layered web enumeration approach to discover directories and files, starting with Layer 1 quick scan.

prompt_templates.title: Service Version Detection
prompt_templates.prompt: Ports 22, 80, and 445 are open on target 192.168.1.100. Perform comprehensive service version detection and identify potential vulnerabilities for each service.

prompt_templates.title: Complete Reconnaissance Workflow
prompt_templates.prompt: Conduct a full reconnaissance workflow on target 10.10.10.20 following all phases: port discovery, service detection, web enumeration, and specific service enumeration. Provide a comprehensive JSON report with recommended next steps.
prompt_templates.scenario: Comprehensive security assessment of authorized target

Discovered open ports:

- Port 80 (HTTP)
- Port 443 (HTTPS)

Next, I recommend performing service version detection on these ports to identify specific software versions and potential vulnerabilities.

output_examples.output:

Layer 1 - Quick directory scan with common wordlist:

Discovered paths:

best_practices: Always verify proper authorization before performing any reconnaissance activities on target systems
Use the layered scanning approach to balance thoroughness with efficiency, escalating from quick to comprehensive scans only when needed
Save all scan outputs in structured JSON format for consistent documentation and easy integration with reporting tools
anti_patterns: Do not scan systems without explicit written authorization from the system owner
Avoid running aggressive scans directly without first attempting quick reconnaissance to understand the target environment
Never use reconnaissance findings to attempt unauthorized access or exploitation outside the approved scope

faq.question: Is this skill safe to use for learning penetration testing?
faq.answer: Yes, this skill provides educational content about reconnaissance methodologies. However, you must only apply these techniques in authorized environments such as your own lab systems, CTF competitions, or with explicit written permission from system owners.

faq.question: Does this skill perform actual network scanning?
faq.answer: No, this skill only provides knowledge and methodologies. Claude Code would need to execute the documented commands using the Bash tool, and you must ensure you have proper authorization before running any security scanning tools.

faq.question: What tools do I need installed to use this skill?
faq.answer: You need common penetration testing tools like nmap, gobuster, nikto, and other utilities mentioned in the skill. These are typically available in security-focused Linux distributions like Kali Linux or Parrot OS.

faq.question: Can I use this skill for production network assessments?
faq.answer: This skill provides foundational knowledge suitable for authorized security assessments. However, production assessments require additional considerations like client agreements, scope documentation, and professional pentesting methodologies beyond what this skill covers.

faq.question: What is the layered reconnaissance approach?
faq.answer: The layered approach uses three escalation levels: Layer 1 performs quick scans with default settings, Layer 2 runs comprehensive scans with aggressive parameters if Layer 1 yields little information, and Layer 3 uses alternative tools or manual techniques when automated scans are insufficient.

faq.question: How does this skill help with CTF challenges?
faq.answer: The skill provides systematic methodologies for discovering hidden services, directories, and vulnerabilities in CTF machines. The structured JSON output templates help organize findings, and the layered approach prevents wasting time on overly aggressive scans when quick enumeration suffices.
